content.description: Start with right hand on the undercling, left hand on the terrible sloper. Use the obvious left foot to pull your body onto the slab and use the sharp crimps to beached whale the rest of your body onto the slab.
content.location: It starts on the far right of the boulder, to the right of the big missing chunk that ends up being a foothold.

content.description:
This route climbs right to left and basically ends with the same top-out as 'Far-Right Overhang.'  

  Work left using the underclings and holds on the overhang, staying low.  Work your way to the start of the bulge and top-out right. 

  Continuing the traverse left across the bulge and topping out on Loneliest Climber likely adds a grade or two.
content.location: Start on the right side of the boulder and up the hill a little bit.  Feet start on the obvious small ledges. Right hand is either on a big side-pull or up a bit higher to a crimp.  Left hand starts waist-level on a small undercling.

content.description: Start on the start holds of White Trash Beach Bash (left hand sloper, right hand undercling) and traverse through Thundercling to Right Overhang, then top out.
content.location: Starts to the right of the big missing chunk near the tree

content.description: Start on the start holds to White Trash Beach Bash, and traverse left through Thundercling to Right Overhang, and top out.
content.location: Start right of the big missing chunk on the rock, over near the tree.

content.description: Head up the tallest part of the boulder on the flat face.  Great problem.
content.location: Straight up the best, and tallest part of the boulder.

content.description: Same start as the Lonliest Climber in Mankato, and traverse all the way left. There is a large reddish brown spot on the far left side of the rock. As soon as the spot is directly to your left, make your way up to the top of the boulder. It is bunch of small crimps the whole way over and up
Grab the obvious jugs and go
content.location: On the far left side of the boulder by the tree. It’s the weird indent with some obvious jugs.

content.description: Head straight up the side of the boulder with a good left hand side pull and right hand pinch. Consistently good left hands, consistently mediocre right hands.
content.location: Right to the left of the weird brown spot

content.description: Bring a brush and maybe you'll find more holds!  Thin moves up a slabby face.
content.location: Start to the left of the Loneliest Climber in Mankato, head straight up the face.

content.description: The only sit start problem at the Boulder due to its height. Climb the finger crack straight up using jams.
content.location: On the left side of the boulder

content.description: Start on the obvious huge side-pull, pull through the short overhang and then up the slab.
content.location: The far right side of the boulder on the obvious side-pull.

content.description: Start on a decent left hand sidepull/pinch with right hand lower on a undercling/sidepull.  Make a big move up to the right arete (or small moves on VERY small holds).  Then climb straight up the arete to the top.
content.location: Start is to the right of Loneliest Climber, on a decent side-pull and an OK right hand sidepull down lower (just left of the bulge).  Climbs the obvious bulge and arete.

content.description:
This 10 foot high boulder is some weird kind of granite/quartzite (Geologists??) and has some fun problems.  Some of the holds are sharp and all the problems are standing starts.   

  Again, it may or may not lie on private property.  Just climb it and be respectful. 

  Bring a brush!!!
